text: @Rosewood_Farm @JamieMc76633051 @GeorgeMonbiot @DaveThroupEA @EnvAgency @HelenStace_HWT I think we are basically both singing from the same hymn sheet.
@timthefruit @JamieMc76633051 @GeorgeMonbiot @DaveThroupEA @EnvAgency @HelenStace_HWT compensation for a cheap food policy in the UK, not a subsidy to support farming.

@timthefruit @JamieMc76633051 @GeorgeMonbiot @DaveThroupEA @EnvAgency @HelenStace_HWT I don't think we can say for sure what ELMS is at the moment but all it's predecessors have acted more like compensation for economic loss rather than subsidy. You have to consider the impact that removing the subsidy would have. It is also, basically, acting more like

RT @RobGMacfarlane: The majority of Earth's chalk streams & rivers are found in England; fragile, extraordinary ecologies.
But they're dyin‚Ä¶
@EnvAgency @DefraGovUK What about #NaturalCapital ? https://t.co/1bADH6usAK
@Bull_of_the_Bog @eastern_ifca @EnvAgency Absolutely, a waste. Below minimum size at 6 inches.

@Rosewood_Farm @JamieMc76633051 @GeorgeMonbiot @DaveThroupEA @EnvAgency @HelenStace_HWT But ELMS is a subsidy. Don't get me wrong I have no problem with public money for public goods in fact I support it. But the question remains how many farms in UK would be financially viable without any input of public funds?

text:
@HSvedang @elverdave @SEGandrewK @DefraGovUK @CITES @EnvAgency Nope. The stock is increasing due to influx in our rivers and lakes, like lake IJsselmeer. Stocking mostly happens in closed waters & stocking is a century old! 

By the way, did you miss the enormous influx in the UK last year? We got some of that over the past years too.

@palingvissers @HSvedang @SEGandrewK @DefraGovUK @CITES @EnvAgency The glass eel recruitment on the river Severn Uk is increasing every year but this season we can‚Äôt sell to any one for restocking @CITES @DefraGovUK @EnvAgency @BorisJohnson

@palingvissers @elverdave @SEGandrewK @DefraGovUK @CITES @EnvAgency Ridiculous and impertinent comment. Hydropower is a constructed problem. ICES says stop fishing.

urls.title: Transforming the Trent Valley
urls.description: The Washlands is an extensive piece of natural land that follows the river through to the heart of Burton upon Trent. The vision, informed by consultation with key stakeholders and the local community, addresses how to best balance the regular flooding of the area with the need for public access and recreation, whilst promoting nature conservation and a more environmentally sustainable approach to green space management. Through our natural heritage project, known as Living Floodplains, we will help to

text: In January we will be carrying out some ground investigations and digging temporary test pits across the #BurtonWashlands. These will provide an insight into the geology of the Washlands informing biodiversity proposals. @EnvAgencyMids @eaststaffsbc Visit https://t.co/JJIcU3M5dy https://t.co/5np02Bhmlw
